prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band6 H2S2 @ 265.368 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations cover the H2S2 line at 265.368 GHz and two other H2S2 lines centered at 266.2 and 266.4 GHz with higher values of Eu at the upper sideband. At the same time, the H2S2 line at 251.424 and two other H2S2 lines centered at 252.2 and 252.4 with higher values of Eu are observed at the lower sideband. A total of 8 HS2 transitions are also covered in this science goal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The IRAS16293-2422 binary system has an angular size of about 8”, but the emission of the sulfur species is expected to come from the inner hot cores, with an angular size of 2" (Wakelam et al. 2004).
Since we look for the detection of new molecules, we do not need to spatially resolve the emission within the hot corinos, so the angular resolution yielded with the most compact 12m-Array configuration is enough for every science goal.
We have used source A as reference for the line intensities calculations. The central radial velocity of IRAS16293-2422 A is 3.2 km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011) and its excitation temperature is ~100 K (Ceccarelli et al. 2000). The detected lines have an average FWHM of 2,6km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2011), with a derived H2S abundance of 5E-7 (Wakelam et al. 2004). On the other hand, by using our APEX observations, we have extracted an upper limit for the H2S2 and HS2 abundance of 4% relative to H2S toward IRAS16293-2422. To estimate the expected intensities for the rotational transitions, we have assumed a conservative abundance of 1% relative to H2S, and we have combined these data with the predictions made by H. Mueller for H2S2 and those of HS2 provided by the Cologne Database for Molecular Spectroscopy. In order to clearly detect and identify new species, a signal to noise (S/N) ratio of 6 is usually required, although a S/N ratio of 3 may be considered a detection.
In this particular science goal, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 265,368 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) at the upper sideband. According to our intensities estimates, with a sensitivity of 4,69 mJy we would detect the transition with a S/N = 6 . Selecting another spectral window within the same baseband allow us to cover two unresolved HS2 transitions at 265.987 GHz. We have selected two other spectral windows within the oher baseband at the upper sideband to cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios, with two more HS2 unresolved transitions in one of them. At the same time, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 251,424 GHz at the lower sideband. Another spectral window within the same baseband allow us to cover two unresolved HS2 transitions at 252.092GHz. We have selected two other spectral windows in another baseband to cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios, with two more HS2 unresolved transitions in one of them. Table 1 in the scientific justification presents the transitions expected to be detected with a S/N ratio higher than 3. A good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines, so a correlator mode with 117.188 MHz bandwidth and a spectral resolution of 0.138 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, but, in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, an spectral average of 2 has been selected, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,159 km/s at the representative frequency. A data rate higher than 6 MB/s is needed to cover all the desired transitions. The bandwidth used for sensitivity is slightly wider (0,2 km/s) to optimize the observing time. The angular resolution requested is 1.4”, corresponding to the synthesized beamsize of the most compact 12m-Array configuration. The observing time requested is 1.31 hrs. None non-standard choices need to be justified.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band4 H2S2 @ 139.8 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations cover several H2S2 lines at 139.8 GHz with Eu ranging from Eu=7 K to Eu=21 K.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this particular science goal, we plan to cover up to 23 H2S2 transitions at approximately 139 GHz, using four spectral windows with a total bandwidth of 468.752 MHz. According to our intensities estimates, with a sensitivity of 5.65 mJy we would detect the transition at 139,864 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) with a S/N = 6 . 7 more transitions would be detected with a higher S/N ratio, plus 3 transitions with 3<S/N<6 (see Table 1 in the scientific justification for more details). Again, a good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines. A correlator mode with 117,118 MHz bandwidth and a spectral resolution of 0.131 km/s has been chosen for each baseband, and a spectral average of 2 has been selected in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, leading to a spectral resolution of 0.151 km/s at the representative frequency. A data rate higher than 6 MB/s is needed to cover all the desired transitions. The bandwidth used for sensitivity is slightly wider (0.2 km/s) to optimize the observing time. The angular resolution requested is 2.6”, corresponding to the synthesized beamsize of the most compact 12m-Array configuration. Complementary ACA observations are not needed. The observing time requested for this science goal is 1.24 hrs. None non-standard choices need to be justified.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 H2S2 @ 293.3 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations cover the H2S2 line at 293.256 GHz with Eu= 50 K, and two other lines at 294.1 GHz and 294.2 GHz with Eu=50 K. At the same time, the H2S2 line at 279.312 with Eu=44K, and two other lines at 280.2 and 280.3 with higher values of Eu are observed at the lower sideband. 4 HS2 transitions could also be observed with this science goal

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In this particular science goal, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 293,256 GHz (the representative frequency of the science goal) at the upper sideband. According to our intensities estimates, with a sensitivity of 4,85 mJy we would detect the transition with a S/N = 6 . Selecting another spectral window within the same baseband allow us to cover two resolved HS2 transitions at 292.759 GHz. We have selected two other spectral windows within the other baseband at the upper sideband to cover two more H2S2 transitions with similar values of Eu but lower S/N ratios. At the same time, we plan to detect one H2S2 transition at 279.312 GHz at the lower sideband. Another spectral window within the same baseband allow us to cover two resolved HS2 transitions at 280.023GHz. We have selected two other spectral windows within the other baseband at the lower sideband to cover two more H2S2 transitions with higher values of Eu and lower S/N ratios. Table 1 in the scientific justification present the transitions expected to be detected with a S/N ratio higher than 3. A good spectral resolution will prevent the dilution of the H2S2 line flux in a broader spectral range, increasing the probability of detection of these lines. A correlator mode with 117.188 MHz bandwidth and a spectral resolution of 0.124 km/s has been chosen for each spectral window, and a spectral average of 2 has been selected in order to keep the data rate below 12 MB/s, leading to a spectral resolution of 0,144 km/s at the representative frequency. A data rate higher than 6 MB/s is needed to cover all the desired transitions. The bandwidth used for sensitivity is slightly wider (0,2 km/s) to optimize the observing time. The angular resolution requested is 1.2”, corresponding to the synthesized beamsize of the most compact 12m-Array configuration. The observing time requested is 2.58 hrs. None non-standard choices need to be justified.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Sulfur is strongly depleted in dense clouds and circumstellar regions around YSOs. The missing sulfur might be locked onto the icy mantles of dust grains, initially in the form of H2S. Several S-bearing gas phase molecules such as H2S, SO2 or OCS have been observed in low-mass and high-mass hot cores, with abundances that cannot be explained with current gas-phase chemical models. Recent lab experiments have shown that energetic processing of H2S-bearing ices leads to efficient photolysis of H2S, with H2S2 and HS2 as the main products. We propose to observe several lines of H2S2 toward the hot corino around the IRAS16293-2422 low-mass protostar, where sulfur-bearing molecules are likely released by thermal or photo-desorption. These observations will confirm whether an important fraction of the missing sulfur is contained in H2S2 and HS2, and will provide key information about the poorly known chemical network of sulfur.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
